Cornwell in the military uniform of the Hawaiian royal court]] '''William Henry Cornwell''' (May 30, 1843 – November 18, 1903) was an American businessman, as well as a military colonel and politician of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. He served two separate terms as [[Ministry of Finance (Hawaii)|Minister of Finance]] and was a member of Queen [[Liliuokalani]]'s last cabinet before the [[Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]]. ==Early life== He was born in [[Brooklyn, New York]], and relocated to [[Kingdom of Hawaii|Hawaii]] at an early age with his family where they became involved in sheep ranching in [[Waimea, Hawaii County, Hawaii|Waimea]]. He formed a partnership with James Louzada for a sugar cane plantation on [[Maui]], which was later sold to [[Claus Spreckels]]. Cornwell became a horse breeder, president of the Hawaiian Jockey Club, and a participant in the sport of horse racing.{{cite news|title=Death of Col Cornwell|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|location=Honolulu|date=November 18, 1903|volume=XI|issue=3639|page=1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1903-11-18/ed-1/seq-1/}}; {{cite news|title=Topics of the Day|newspaper=The Independent|location=Honolulu|date=November 18, 1903|volume=XVII|issue=2664|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1903-11-18/ed-1/seq-2/}}; {{cite news|title=Sad News of Death Of Col. Cornwell Comes By Wireless|newspaper=Evening Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=November 18, 1903|volume=XIV|issue=2615|page=1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1903-11-18/ed-1/seq-1/}}; {{cite news|title=Death of Col. Cornwell|newspaper=Evening Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=November 18, 1903|volume=XIV|issue=2615|page=8|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1903-11-18/ed-1/seq-8/}}; {{cite news|title=Death has been busy...|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|location=Honolulu|date=November 19, 1903|volume=XI|issue=3640|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1903-11-19/ed-1/seq-4/}}; {{cite news|title=Died|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|location=Honolulu|date=November 19, 1903|volume=XI|issue=3640|page=7|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1903-11-19/ed-1/seq-7/}}; {{cite news|title=The death of Colonel Wm. H. Cornwell...|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=November 19, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=6641|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-11-19/ed-1/seq-4}}; {{cite news|title=Col. Wm. H. Cornwell Dies At Waikapu Ranch|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=November 19, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=6641|page=8|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-11-19/ed-1/seq-8/|}}; {{cite news|title=Col. Cornwell Dies At Waikapu Ranch|newspaper=The Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|date=November 20, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=95|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1903-11-20/ed-1/seq-2/}}; {{cite news|title=The Late Col. Cornwell|newspaper=The Independent|location=Honolulu|date=November 21, 1903|volume=XVII|issue=2667|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1903-11-21/ed-1/seq-2/}}; {{cite news|title=W. H. Cornwell Dead – Old Timers Dies at Waikapu After Short Illness|newspaper=The Hilo Tribune|location=Hilo|date=November 27, 1903|volume=9|issue=4|page=6|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016339/1903-11-27/ed-1/seq-6/}}; {{cite news|title=The death of Col. W. H. Cornwell removes...|newspaper=The Maui News|location=Wailuku|date=November 21, 1903|volume=VIII|issue=14|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1903-11-21/ed-1/seq-2/}}; {{cite news|title=Death of Col. W. H. Cornwell|newspaper=The Maui News|location=Wailuku|date=November 21, 1903|volume=VIII|issue=14|page=3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1903-11-21/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=November 13, 2016}} ==Political career== Cornwell held the rank of [[Major]] and later [[Colonel]], as a staff member under both King [[Kalākaua]] and Queen [[Liliuokalani]]. During the 1890 legislative assembly, Cornwell served as a member of the House of Nobles, the upper house of the [[legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii|legislature]], for the island of Maui.{{sfn|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918|page=178}} He continued his term in the House during the legislative session of 1892–93, which became known as the "Longest Legislature" for its unprecedented duration of 171 days. On November 1, 1892, he was appointed by Queen Liliuokalani as Minister of Finance and to form the short lived Cornwell Cabinet which consisted of [[Joseph Nāwahī]], [[Charles T. Gulick]] and [[Charles F. Creighton]]. This cabinet existed for less than a day when it was ousted by the legislature with a vote of 26 to 13.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|page=557}} He was re-elected to his vacant legislative seat on December 5.{{sfn|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918|page=182}} On January 13, 1893, Queen Liliuokalani re-appointed him as Minister of Finance to the Parker Cabinet with [[Samuel Parker (Hawaii)|Samuel Parker]], [[John F. Colburn]] and [[Arthur P. Peterson]] after the previous [[George N. Wilcox|Wilcox]] cabinet was voted out by the legislature the day before.{{cite web |url=http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/import/import/Government%20Office%20Holders%20-%20Name%20IMJ/C/Cornwell,%20William%20H.jpg |title=Cornwell, William H. office record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate=June 17, 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news|title=A New Cabinet – Some New Ministers for the Public to Swallow|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=January 14, 1893|volume=XVII|issue=3277|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1893-01-14/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=November 12, 2016}} She had chosen these men specifically to support her plan of promulgating a new constitution while the legislature was not in session.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=581–583}} Publisher and philanthropist [[Thurston Twigg-Smith]], the grandson of annexation leader [[Lorrin A. Thurston]], made the case that Cornwell was part of a royal inner [[cabal]] of the queen's own cabinet ministers who worked to oust the monarchy.{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|p=61}} She attempted to promulgate a [[Proposed 1893 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii|new constitution]], but Cornwell and the rest of the cabinet were either opposed to or reluctant to sign the new constitution. Their opposition was one of the causes which ultimately led to her [[Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii|overthrow]] by the [[Committee of Safety (Hawaii)|Committee of Safety]] headed by Thurston.{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|pages=64–67}} After the overthrow, Cornwell and the rest of the Parker Cabinet were removed from office.{{harvnb|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918|page=188}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=A Provisional Government|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1893-01-18/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=November 6, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=January 18, 1893|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} After the overthrow of the monarchy and the annexation of Hawaii to the United States, Cornwell became a member of the [[Democratic Party of Hawaii|Democratic Party]] and served as a delegate to [[1900 Democratic National Convention]] for the [[Territory of Hawaii]]. He died at his home at [[Waikapu]], Maui, on November 18, 1903, of heart disease. His remains were taken to Honolulu for his funeral and he was buried at the [[Oahu Cemetery]] in Honolulu.{{cite sign|title=Grave Marker of William H. Cornwell|type=|location=Honolulu, HI|institution=[[Oahu Cemetery]]}}{{cite news|title=Col. Cornwell's Body Arrives – Remains Of Dead National Committeeman Brought From Maui On The Mauna Loa|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|location=Honolulu|date=November 20, 1903|volume=XI|issue=3641|page=5|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1903-11-20/ed-1/seq-5/}}; {{cite news|title=Freak Of Sea Off Punaluu|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=November 21, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=6643|page=7|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-11-21/ed-1/seq-7/}}; {{cite news|title=Cornwell Funeral – Services at the Central Union Church on Sunday|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=November 20, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=6642|page=9|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-11-20/ed-1/seq-9/}}; {{cite news|title=Col. Cornwell's Funeral Sunday|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=November 21, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=6643|page=3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-11-21/ed-1/seq-3/}}; {{cite news|title=Cornwell Funeral – Services at the Central Union Church on Sunday – The Masonic Ritual Is Also Carried Out – Interment Made in Family Plot at Nuuanu Cemetery – Friends Turn Out in Force|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=November 23, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=6644|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-11-23/ed-1/seq-4/}}; {{cite news|title=Cornwell Funeral – Services at the Central Union Church on Sunday|newspaper=The Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|date=November 24, 1903|volume=XXXVIII|issue=96|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1903-11-24/ed-1/seq-2/}}; {{cite news|title=The Cornwell Funeral|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|location=Honolulu|date=November 21, 1903|volume=XI|issue=3642|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1903-11-21/ed-1/seq-2/}}; {{cite news|title=Funeral of W. H. Cornwell – Services At Masonic Temple And Central Union Church – Interment in Nuuanu|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|location=Honolulu|date=November 23, 1903|volume=XI|issue=3643|page=7|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1903-11-23/ed-1/seq-7/}}; {{cite news|title=Topics of the Day|newspaper=The Independent|location=Honolulu|date=November 25, 1903|volume=XVII|issue=2670|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1903-11-25/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=November 15, 2016}} ==Personal life== He married twice: Blanche Macfarlane (1853–1880) and Josephine Colvin, who survived him, and had three children by his first wife: William Henry Cornwell, Jr., Blanche C. Walker. wife of J. H. Walker; and Kate J. Braymer, wife of A. A. Braymer.{{cite news|title=W. H. Cornwell's Will|newspaper=Evening Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=November 30, 1903|volume=XIV|issue=2624|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1903-11-30/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=November 13, 2016}} == Citations == {{Reflist|30em}} == References == *{{cite book|author=Hawaii|editor-last=Lydecker|editor-first=Robert Colfax|volume=|title=Roster Legislatures of Hawaii, 1841–1918|location=Honolulu|publisher=Hawaiian Gazette Company|year=1918|url=https://archive.org/details/rosterlegislatur00hawarich|oclc=60737418|ref={{harvid|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918}}}} *{{cite book|last=Kuykendall|first=Ralph Simpson|authorlink=Ralph Simpson Kuykendall|title=The Hawaiian Kingdom 1874–1893, The Kalakaua Dynasty|url=http://www.ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?c=kingdom3&l=en|volume=3|year=1967|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=978-0-87022-433-1|oclc=500374815|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Twigg-Smith|first=Thurston|authorlink=Thurston Twigg-Smith|title=Hawaiian Sovereignty: Do the Facts Matter?|year=1998|publisher=Goodale Publishing|location=Honolulu|isbn=978-0-9662945-0-7|oclc=39090004|ref=harv}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *{{Find a Grave|45017110|Col William Henry Cornwell, Jr}} {{Hawaiian Ministers of Finance}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cornwell, William Henry}} [[Category:1843 births]] [[Category:1903 deaths]] [[Category:People from Brooklyn]] [[Category:Kingdom of Hawaii politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Kingdom of Hawaii House of Nobles]] [[Category:Kingdom of Hawaii Finance Ministers]] [[Category:Hawaii Democrats]] [[Category:People from Maui]] [[Category:Burials at Oahu Cemetery]] [[Category:Kingdom of Hawaii military officers]] [[Category:People associated with the Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]]
